title: 1 Million Members, 100 Million Trees: How Brazil’s Socialist Farmers Are Fighting Big Ag

last_post.content:
Municipal nurseries can be a huge driver of social and political change. The Landless Workers Movement in Brazil are doing agroecological projects by making collective nurseries to help revive the native ecosystem and organize the working class.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KiXkUPeMx9I

They are an intersectional ecosocialist movement with Black and Indigenous people leading the fight against agro-businesses and the capitalist class that exploits the people and the ecosystem. They also do land occupations to take back land for the people. Deforestation is a major issue in Brazil, this is done almost exclusively by corporations and wealthy land owners who only see the land as a profit machine, and not a delicate ecosystem that can be managed in responsible ways borrowing from the experience of the local people. We could learn a lot from movements like this, and tailor tactics and methods to our bioregions and communities. By learning methods from agroecology, permaculture, and indigenous communities we can figure out better ways to sustain the ecosystem and each other.

Land occupations and squats to build ecosocialist - intersectional - and communal life while repairing the ecosystem with native biodiversity is amazing. Giving land back to indigenous people, and the working class to steward the land is a worthy fight.https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1sZ0FMJqefw

#solarpunk #ecosocialism

📝 Today CISA
published a new site (https://cisa.gov/securebydesign), and launched a paper titled "Shifting the Balance of Cybersecurity Risk: Principles and Approaches for Security-by-Design and -Default".
See https://cisa.gov/resources-tools/resources/secure-by-design-and-default
#SecureByDesign

🔐 In this guidance, the authoring agencies urge technology manufacturers to move the burden of staying cyber safe away from customers, many of whom are unable to afford the security tools and staff required to do so.

✅ Although the guide has technical guidance, I encourage you to check out the core principles. They are:
1. Take ownership of the security outcomes of the customer
2. Embrace radical transparency and accountability
3. Build organizational structure to achieve these goals

🌐 I'm especially proud to have ten seals on this doc, including so many co-authoring international partners. Thanks to the team that managed that inter-agency process!
And mega thanks to
@jackhcable and @grantdasher
and the *many* other people who contributed!

📧 We're hoping this guide will create a lot of conversation and ideas on how manufacturers can make their products #SecureByDesign. If you have suggestions, please drop us a line at SecureByDesign@cisa.dhs.gov

title: Ethiopia recruits 500,000 women for domestic work in Saudi Arabia

last_post.content:
My latest story for Al Jazeera:
#Ethiopia seeks to recruit and deploy 500,000 women to work as migrant domestic workers in Saudi Arabia, as a solution for unemployment and forex shortages.

Human rights activists condemn the initiative and say it endangers poor vulnerable women, citing rampant abuse, exploitation and death of migrant workers that goes unpunished in #SaudiArabia.

The scale of planned recruitment, and the government's direct involvement are unprecedented.

https://www.aljazeera.com/features/2023/4/17/ethiopia-recruits-500000-women-for-domestic-work-in-saudi-arabia

The `in` clause in an action pattern is used either with a room or a region; `in X` means something much like:

if (X is a room and the location of the actor is X) or (X is a region and the actor is regionally in X)

Note that this is very much *not* the same thing as a `when the actor is in X` clause! `the actor is in` is a use of the "to be in" verb, which means the reversed containment relation. As described here:

https://zedlopez.github.io/i7doc/WI_6.html#section_11

it's kind of screwy.
